name: Turkey: France-style censorship, at scale
excerpt: Turkish censorship law is similar to France's but its application is more widespread. It shows how the tools of censorship can be used with full force.
html:
Cumhuriyet

What happens if government doesn’t want to spread certain news at the age of the internet? As concerns on national security and terror attacks increase, so do the legal and judicial tools to monitor and censor media outlets.

On this matter, Turkey has always been notorious with media crackdowns and governmental pressure on journalists. In RSF’s 2016 World Press Freedom Index, Turkey is ranked 151st out of 180 and according to Twitter Transparency Report released in March 2017, Turkey issues the largest number of censorship requests by court order [1]. This is comes as no surprise, however, as studies established that Twitter radically under-reports censored tweets in Turkey and warned that similar trends might hold for other countries[2].

In this framework, discourses of national defense and public security provide a safe haven for government to practice and legitimize censorship through judicial injunction. The rise in number of court orders goes parallel to the increasing in deadly attacks.

Nevertheless, one of the most scandalous crackdowns has been on Cumhuriyet’s writers and staff, following their famous “Turkish Intelligence Agency (MIT) truck” article. In 2015, editor-in-chief Can Dundar and Ankara representative Erdem Gul have been charged with life imprisonment after the newspaper shared a video showing weaponry transport to Syria.

Cumhuriyet is one of the oldest Turkish newspapers and it has been renowned for its opposition towards government. However, with charges of revealing confidential information and being members of terrorist organization, currently many of the newspapers’ staff including reporters, columnists and executives are in prison.

What was the article about?

In January 2014, the local prosecutor requested the Gendarmerie to stop and search lorries in Adana thought to be carrying weapons to jihadist groups to Syria, at a border crossing point controlled by ISIS (Bab al-Hawa).  The government claimed that the trucks were sending humanitarian aid to Syria and they belonged to the Turkish intelligence agency MIT. The arrest of intelligence agency members by the gendarmerie led to a huge scandal. The prosecutor who ordered the search and all gendarmerie officials who took part were removed from their positions and many of them were charged with life imprisonment.[3]

One year later, in May 2015, Cumhuriyet published an article and a video on their website, claiming that Turkish intelligence were helping to smuggle weaponry to jihadist groups in Syria [see the video here].[4] The video shows security officers inspecting three trucks and uncovering missiles, mortars and anti-aircraft ammunition that were hidden underneath medical aid equipment. The media outlet claims that most of the ammunition was headed to ISIS and al-Qaeda and accused the government of committing a war crime.

After the release of the article, government officials first claimed that the guns were headed to the “Free Syrian Army”, then denied the delivery altogether and shortly after Prime-Minister Ahmet Davutoglu claimed “the humanitarian aid was going to our Turkmen brothers” [5].

On the day the article was published, a court in Adana issued an immediate gag order. All written, visual and online media outlets were banned from reporting or commenting on the scandal and all the content that has been published so far had to be removed under Law Nr. 3713, which is commonly referred as “Anti-Terror Law”.[6] Thus, by the order of the judge, the newspaper had to completely delete the content from its website. Shortly after, two journalists Can Dundar and Erdem Gul were arrested with charges of espionage and treason. Even though they were released after four months, many of the newspapers’ top staff, writers and a reporter are in prison as of April 2017.

How was the content blocked?

How does the government censor media in Turkey?  Once a censorship attempt occurs, several legal and judicial tools are developed to monitor and censor media outlets across the country. Turkish courts and prosecutors have the right to issue gag orders and ask for the removal of all written and online content if deemed necessary. In this case, the discourse of national security plays a huge role to legitimize the court rulings as in the case of Cumhuriyet’s article. Provisions of criminal law, such as Anti-Terror Law, are applied for online content. Thus, court opinions on media censorship rely on  “counter- terrorism, public interest, restoration of public order and prevention of crimes”.[7]

Once a court issues the order, RTÜK (Radio and Television Supreme Council) implements the broadcast ban. As a result, media outlets have to comply with the ban and do not mention or comment the forbidden content. Otherwise, RTÜK has the authority to sanction the broadcasters or even close the media outlets if they violate the orders.

For online material, TIB (Telecommunication and Communication Presidency) has been in charge of implementing the orders of prosecutors since 2007. Its jurisdiction is now transferred to BTK (Information and Communication Technologies Authority) with the declaration of martial law after the coup d’état attempt in July 2016. Under Law No.5651, commonly known as the “Internet Law”, banned content has to be removed within 4 hours once the court order is received by website owners. This law that took effect in 2014 expands TIB’s jurisdiction and allows blockage without prior court order, though it has to be approved by a court within 48 hours.[8] 

In this case, scholars estimate that government’s internet authority TIB banned over 100.000 URLs and domains based on civil-code related complaints. Through TIB’s decision; Youtube, Facebook, Twitter, Instagram have been blocked multiple times with a single court order . If access to a single page cannot be blocked for technical reasons, the law allows ISPs to block an entire domain [9].

ISPs also throttle internet traffic (make internet traffic slow), even if there is no legal ground for them to do so. However, researchers of Turkey Blocks, an independent group that monitors social media censorship, reveal that extrajudicial shutdown of social media applications and network throttling are employed right after terror attacks.[10][11] Access to Cumhuriyet has been throttled by TIB at least three times in last two years.[12] Furthermore, after the “MIT trucks” piece, another Cumhuriyet article, which was on the financial activities of Humanitarian Relief Foundation, an international NGO in relation to jihadist groups, was censored by court order and banned in Turkey.[13]

What’s next?

It is almost a settled law now; at times of domestic crises, government resorts to censor and throttle access to media platforms in Turkey. Despite legal and judicial constraints, journalists still seek digital tools to counter demands of content deletion. On the other hand, regular internet users also try to find alternative ways to circumvent censorship and social media shutdowns through VPN, however, government already ordered ISPs to block access to Tor and VPN services and leading service providers are implementing this order.[14]

Many newspapers are even under the threat of losing their archives. 90-year-old Cumhuriyet is only one of them. Only in July 2016; 45 newspapers, 3 news agencies, 16 TV stations, 23 radio channels and 29 publishing houses have been taken down with charges of making propaganda of terror organizations.[15] And newspaper staff of some closed newspapers claim that government’s trustee delete archives from the servers.[16] There is no confirmation on this matter; however, internet users cannot reach archives of many seized newspapers such as once the country’s one of the top-selling newspapers Zaman, its English-language sister publication Today’s Zaman and Birgün. This method is particularly harsh and terrifying since the purpose of deleting an archive is not only removal of an unwanted content, but also an attempt to wipe out the existence of the newspaper from the history, as if it never existed.
